title: Ekko, The Boy Who Shattered Time

embed.description: Super hyped for the new champion, Ekko. Had to draw him. The picture is based around the original teaser video that was released. After actually seeing his skills in game, I feel like he's portraye...

body: Here's my rendition of the Boy who Shattered Time. I'm super excited for the new character, and thinks he's just what league needs. dontnerfhisult

Well, I'm not on the League narrative team - nor on the League team directly.  So while I can be really impressed by a sweet piece of fan art (such as the one above by Langler), I don't have any useful information to add to the lore threads about him over in Story & Art.  

I can theorize the same as any other player - but that's about it.  Not to mention, Ekko's only on the PBE so far - not even released for realzies yet.  I've not had a chance to play him (late stage, company-wide playtests generally look for good players - and I ain't one!) but I am looking forward to it.  There may still be things that change about him between now and then!

Sorry - I know that's not what you wanted to hear.  I'm like the plain step-sister who turned up to the party instead of the pretty sister - people keep asking me where the other one is!  I just wanna dance, same as everyone else, so to speak.

I AM NOT SHITTING ON YOU BY ANY MEANS. You just might want to sure up your composition and perspective. The bricks he is standing on don't seem to be getting small fast enough to come out of that doorway. But maybe it is that tube venting smoke that is throwing it off.  I like those after images but they make him kind of sedentary in contrast. I mean in his pose not his action. Thumbs up.

I think I see what you mean, I never really established a correct relation between the tiles and how far the wall at the end looks. So the ground looks too high? or on a different angle/plane. I don't think I got his legs right on the ground either, so I'm gonna fix that first. Your advice is really spot on, I've had a problem with stiff characters in a lot of my images. I guess it might stem from having been a portrait painter. I have to try to capture more dynamic poses, motion, and camera angles. I'll try to focus on this for the future. Thanks for the comment!
The after images are yours to right? They look like great poses.
Yea, I drew him two more times, but in much less detail.  Usually the more I render or detail, the less movement it portrays.

I was talking to an artist once that said there is an architect and and an artist in your head. The artists wants to dig into details as soon as possible. You must resist the temptation to start working on fine details before the composition is complete. The task of the architect is to convey the intent of the piece with as little detail as possible. An entire picture is just a bunch of gesture drawings that work well together in a space. The faster you are to jump into details, the less likely you are to scrap the picture when you see that your composition is unrefined. His words. He was pretty cool. Works for Boom or IDW, can't remember whitch.
Just now learning digital art as I've always been more comfortable with a pencil and paper. I am inspired to continue learning after seeing pieces like this be created.

I used to draw on the computer when I was in Junior High, but then became somewhat of a classical portrait painter in oil paints. I studied oils throughout college, and had just made my way back into digital art  recently. (end of last year) Part about learning is expanding horizons and trying out everything, but you must look at a lot of art, and know what can make a decent picture. After you accomplish that, your skill and ability will reveal itself through any tools or mediums you may use. Once you are comfortable with the tablet/photoshop as a tool (knowing what it can and cannot do in comparison to pencil and paper), you'll start seeing great results.
